captions.text: Just Like Other Animals presents
Does true love exist?
Around Kenya in 20 days
Hi, this is Just Like Other Animals, the programme on the origin of people.
Today we will talk about true love.
"The two shall become one flesh and one soul, for better and for worse...
to love and to cherish 'til death do us part."
This is how we imagine true love, but we doubt if it really exists.
Follow me, my viewer, and I will show you such a love.
If I will swim in this romantic African pond...
or wade in this picturesque river with hippos, a very touching love story will begin inside me.
A tiny organism called schistosoma lives in fresh water in tropical countries.
The schistosoma is a parasitic flatworm.
The infectious form of the schistosoma, known as cercariae, leaves its intermediary host, the freshwater snail...
and swims around searching for a new warm-blooded host.
I could become a very good home for the schistosoma. But please, not in me.
In some African countries, almost everyone is contaminated. So, the schistosoma doesn't need my help to find a new home.
The cercariae burrows the skin of a human host and enters the bloodstream.
It travels through the heart, lungs and many other interesting places before it finally reaches the meeting point of all schistosomas.
The liver.
Here, the cercariae ends its journey and starts to rapidly grow, while waiting for its better half.
In this case, "the better half" is meant literally, as females and males are truly made for each other.
The female is very thin, and the male is more robust and shaped as a canoe.
The male possesses a body grove called a gynaecophoral canal, where the female takes up residence for her whole life.
The female crawls into her Mr. Right's gynecophoral canal.
And their family canoe departs for a honeymoon in the veins.
They swim against the bloodstream, just like the salmon swims upstream, against currents to spawn.
Each species of the schistosoma has its own safe haven, where they settle down and start a family.
Some schistosomas choose the large intestine, some pick the bladder.
There are so many places in our body where one can build a love nest.
The lovers attach themselves to the chosen spot, and their eternal honeymoon begins.
They make love every day. The female lays eggs and the male feeds her with what he sucks up from the surrounding tissue.
And even if the female suddenly dies, he continues to carry her in his arms for a couple of days.
After all, his life has no meaning without her.
It's very sad but true. Great love often means great dependence.
And here's another incredible love story, also hidden from human eyes.
Somewhere here, on the bottom of the ocean lives Mrs. Anglerfish.
She is not at all beautiful. Short fins, small eyes, a wide mouth and a wrinkled belly.
In addition, she has a rod with a lantern on her nose and a fairly large wart on her side.
But Mrs. Anglerfish is not upset by her appearance, because she lives in darkness and nobody cares what she looks like.
On the contrary, her ugliness is quite useful.
Fish bait the lantern on her nose and go straight into the huge mouth and belly that can be stretched to the size of a zeppelin.
And the wart on her side is her own Mr. Anglerfish. And this is how he got there.
Young single males are constantly searching for a female using their sense of smell.
The bigger and older their future wife, the better.
After meeting his bride, the male latches onto her soft flesh with his sharp teeth and stays there.
Over time, his lips grow into the female's skin, their blood systems merge, and the male's life becomes fully parasitic.
The anglerfish male remains attached to the same female his whole life, eating at her expense and providing her with his sperm.
Yes, he is quite small. But always at hand.
The male is so small because he stops growing in order not to devour his lovely spouse.
Sometimes six or seven 2 cm males peacefully co-exist on one 1.5 m female, on full board.
Once, the anglerfish males were thought to be a separate parasitic species.
So, the phrase "I love you, my parasite" was not invented by us.
But we need to remember that the main word here is "love", not "parasite".
We were Just Like Other Animals. Bye.
Today I will tell you about true love!
Let's take a male schistosoma...
and a female and see what they will do.
- Get in my gynecophoral canal, baby! - Oh, he knows such intelligent words!
It's quite cosy here.
They will stay together forever and leave the liver to build a happy family life.
Why don't we go to IKEA today!
Oh, God, it's starting...

title: Шистосомы и удильщики: люблю тебя, паразита! // Все как у зверей в Кении
